intro: Ranunculus nivalis f. subglobosus, commonly known as the alpine buttercup, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to high-altitude regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It features showy, yellow flowers with 5–15 petals, typically arranged in a cup-like structure. The plant has finely divided, fern-like leaves that are adapted to cold, mountainous environments. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky slopes. Its blooming period occurs in late spring to early summer, making it a notable species in alpine botany.
